TELEGRAFIC.
(By Special Dispatch.)
WINNIPEG, Jan. 12.
A special extra Canada Gazette was issued last evening proclaiming the Act granting representation to the North-West. The Act was afterwards withdrawn by special dispatch. The whole explanation was that copies had been issued before the order of council was passed.
A big flood mill is being erected by Mitchell, of Montreal, at Regina, which will have a capacity of one thousand barrels a day, and will be the largest in the Northwest. It will also include storage, grain elevators and warehouses in the leading grain markets of Manitoba.

His Lordship Bishop Macdonald, Rev. Father John Lee, and Mr. Smith, who left for the east a few days ago by way of Chicago, will proceed direct to Europe without stopping at Regina, as there are no American cities as far as their intention. Archbishop Taché has returned from Europe. In about a month he expects to leave for Rome to be installed at the general meeting of the Oblate Order, which takes place in April.

The Liberal Conservative Association of Winnipeg met last night and elected Mr. J. H. Macdonald as its candidate for Commissioner.

Sir John Lester Kaye is in the city and has completed arrangements for the Department of Agriculture for the establishment of ten large farms in the Northwest. He leaves for England early in the spring to appeal for subscriptions on his farms to be commenced in the spring.

It is understood that there has been no new appointments under the Territorial Act recently put into operation in the North-West. The officers in each district will continue to perform their duties as formerly. In all probability Alberta will remain divided as at present, with offices at Calgary and Edmonton.

Mr. Daly has been appointed Commissioner of the North-West Territories. It is stated that papers for the Dominion elections have been issued, and that the returns will be sent to Ottawa by February 1st, polling on the 15th.

WINNIPEG, Jan. 12.
The political situation is still the topic of conversation throughout the West, and eastern and central Canada and both parties are making preparations.

Sir John is in the city, having conferred with the leaders of the party and endeavoring to strengthen the newspaper situation. Provincial elections will take place on February 15th, except probably in the North-West. The withdrawal of notice of proclamation has been due to the fact that the signature of Lord Salisbury has not been omitted, but it will doubtless be signed shortly.

Sir Charles Tupper will immediately enter the cabinet as Minister of Finance and head the Conservative party of Nova Scotia.

The situation in Winnipeg is uncertain. The Conservatives have made no movement toward the election, while the minister to Sir Donald A. Smith, though there is a difference of opinion. The Liberals talk of nominating Isaac Campbell.

Lord Eldonshay, better known as Sir Samuel Leonard, died suddenly while having conferences with Lord Salisbury. Death resulted from failure of the heart muscles.

Eastern morning papers today contain no indication of Dominion election, but reports probably will be heard soon in Halifax. No report has yet been received from Regina, but it is expected that a Northwest representation will not be proclaimed until Saturday.

Deputy Sheriff Ross returned from St. Louis last night. Mr. Ross and Chester Thompson left for Portage la Prairie by special train.

The annual meeting of the Bandits was held at Assiniboia last week on Tuesday evening, but owing to a poor attendance the meeting was called off. Mr. Davis' store, business, the election of officers, etc. Full attendance requested.

The first carnival of the season in the Saskatchewan Hunt took place last evening. Though the weather was not very cold, the attendance was expected. Mr. Cook took the prizes of Miss and Miss Anne Cook, and Mr. Cook took the prize of P. A. C. band was present.

We visited O. Nelson's store, the second block, the other day and examined the new display of clothing cutters, which Mr. Nelson has ordered. We also examined his harness from the Taylor & Co., of Winnipeg, which took over forty-five pieces last fall, and we consider them the finest harnesses that have ever been imported into the country.

Mr. Goumas, Inspector of Police Works, at St. Boniface by invitation of the council, gave an account of a couple of months, touching upon the construction of the new police station. Mr. Goumas has been superintending the erection of the courthouse and jail building and gave an interesting explanation of the locking and the arrangement of the cell doors. The court-room was fitted up by the Inspector and contains a substantial building at much less cost than was expected.
DOMINION ELECTIONS

The Dominion elections, apart from the Northwest—were expected to take place on the 15th of February. We treat them as a great opportunity to strengthen our belief that the people of Canada prefer the present Government—or policy pursued by the present Government—to any other. They believe that they would be better off in a government for the benefit of all the nations of the world, and not for foreigners; that they believe in Canadianism for Canada, the same as the Americans believe in Americanism.

A convention composed of friends of the country and those interested in different settlements of the northwestern district, will take place next Friday, the 21st inst., at Prince Albert, for the purpose of nominating a candidate to canvass for the constituency. It is to be hoped that sectional considerations will not be allowed to interfere with the selection of a suitable person, but that all will submit to the majority rule. Mr. Hughes, who was elected chairman, has been very active in the movement and has been very successful in getting the support of prominent men.

THE BRITISH CRY ("")

Repeal is again being agitated in Nova Scotia, and Hon. A. G. Jones, one of Mr. Macdonald's ministers, and the leader of the Liberal party, has announced his intention to stand for the constituency of Halifax. His decision is based on the fact that he is convinced that repeal is essential for the prosperity of Nova Scotia.

INDIAN AFFAIRS

There is an election going on in Prince Albert, N.W.T., and Mr. Campbell has been elected chairman of the committee. The Indians have been promised a great deal, but it remains to be seen whether these promises will be fulfilled.

BIDDING FOR NOVA SCOTIA

The Hon. Timothy Warren Anglin, who represented a Nova Scotia constituency for many years, has retired from politics. He has been replaced by Mr. Blake, who has promised to do everything in his power to improve conditions in Nova Scotia.

EDITORIAL NOTES.

If the present government of Northcote the Premier, brings forth a good man, and the present Imperial Government, weak at least one of its chief mainstays.

Andrew Lepine, who was concerned in the late Red River troubles, who seems most likely to be during the late troubles, has obtained the reinstatement of all his civil rights, which he had lost accepting a commission of the then Governor.

We have received a special number of the Kingston Whig, in which is given a history of the Whig party and its prominent citizens for the last half century. To old Kingstonites, the illustrations, portraits, writings and old faces, and the historical reminiscences, cannot but prove interesting.

The Torrens system of land tenure went into operation in the North-west Territories on January 1st. The adoption of this system so early in our career will prove a great boon to people who are not yet settled, but owing to the fact that the transfer from the Crown will be made under it in many cases and land will be sold by those few hands since patents were issued, it will avoid future complications. Under the Act, the surveyor-general may make no appointments save where made as yet, and the present officers will continue to hold their positions.

At Halifax Mr. Anglin said:—They (the Government) have mismanaged affairs in the Northwest by sending out to the people who came there, the men who went there, when they were ashamed to appoint to any other position in Canada, but sent them through for such unfortunate people—to take care and ill treat them. While there may be an odd black sheep in every flock, there have to be hundreds to make up the Indian department officials of the Northwest, as a body, will compare very favourably with any other branch of the public service or the hon. gentlemen who slander them. Besides many of them were appointed by the late Sir John A. Macdonald. At the momentality of the Indians, it is notorious fact that it was a very few orders long before any Canadian officials came into the country.

TERRITORIAL NEWS.

BATTLEFORD.

The Herald of Dec. 20th says:—Mr. E. M. Smith, of the Battle River reserve last week, and discovered the disease which had been reported to him as smallpox was the scourge. He said the disease was not as prevalent on the reserves, but it is now connected with their treat- ment by the Government, or, as he terms it, the Government. They have an abundance of fresh beef and fish in addition to bacon, and it is said by those who have been amongst them that much of the sickness is due to their gluttony.

COMMUNICATIONS.

EDMONTON.

The Bulletin, Dec. 11th says:—Jas. Noon, absent from Saddle Lake on Thursday, where he has been th- ing out the crop of the Indian settlement. Telegraph communication was opened with Fort Saskatchewan on Wednesday. W. H. Smith, Esq., has returned.

A blackfoot half-breed who has been in the employ of J. Norris, senior, for some time past, was dangerously injured Tuesday of this week, and is now confined in the police cells here. He was examined by Capt. Griesbach on Friday morning, and will be taken to Ft. Saskatchewan today.

A LITTLE HASTY.

By the Editor of The Times.

When I thought to call attention to a reference in the Winnipeg Weekly Free Press of Dec. 23rd to a letter of Rev. Dr. Jardine, written to the editor of the Sketch, with regard to the farmers of this district. It seems to me that that gentleman has been a little hasty in his remarks regarding the condition of this place. Dr. Jardine "on arriving" at Prince Albert, in a wonderful short space of time, found that "a few good Scotch farmers" were successful, "but they were very few," and that "there is a great increase in the number of industrious and intelligent men" come and settle here, the country as regards Prince Albert will go the way of the rest.

Dr. Jardine, "on arriving" here, without having had time to get to the conclusions that he "very soon" will arrive at, and ignorant, and that these "intelligent Scotch farmers" were Scotch. Now Mr. Elliot, I am not sure, but I believe he was Scotch, but his doctrine is certainly demonstrative from Dr. Jardine in behalf of other settlers west of the Rocky Mountains. Let him go west, south and east of Prince Albert, and he will see equally as prosperous and intelligent Scotch farmers as the population of Providence in the drought of the last three years, at which we do not rejoice. These people made the country their home, and where they have gained experience in farming, having been a considerable time engaged in occupations other than farming, they are now farmers, as Dr. Jardine thinks they are others that are as industrious and intelligent, and have the determination to "do or die" as the Scotch farmers of the East.

I think Dr. Jardine would do well to acquire a little more experience of the difficulties of the West, and his conclusions, he would attain what he apparently lacks. He not only shames a straightforward and respectable class over the districts west of this our country a barn by such representations that they cannot be easily eradicated from the eyes of the world.

If Dr. Jardine is a gentleman, which his title would denote, he should retract his expression made, as if he were, without due reflection, and apologize.

By giving space to this letter in your valuable paper you would confer a favor on a great many industrious and intelligent farmers, and Mr. Elliot.

C. A. Adams.
Red Deer Hill, Jan. 9th, 1877.
